If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an about estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XIX, § D) Sec. 50-192. - Billing; delinquencies and penalties. (a) Bills to customers for water and sewer service shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at the city hall. (b) Failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. (c) The failure of water or sewer users to timely pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: (1) Nonpayment within 20 days from the due date will be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account. (2) Nonpayment within 40 days from the date due will result in the water being shut off from the water user's property. (3) Nonpayment for 60 days after original due date will allow the city, in addition to all other rights and remedies, to terminate service to the property. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XVII, § A) Sec. 50-193. - Disconnection for nonpayment; reconnection fees. (a) Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, such security deposit or additional security deposit as may be required by the mayor and council is made, and a reconnection fee as provided in the city's fee schedule is paid for each meter reconnected. (b) Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, in the event reconnection is not requested within a reasonable time, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XVIII, § B; Ord. of 2006, § VII; Ord. of 8-28-2006, § VIII) Sec. 50-194. - Disconnection of service for reasons other than nonpayment. The city reserves a right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse. (2) Consumer's willful disregard of the city's rules. (3) Emergency repairs. (4) Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control. (5) Legal processes. (6) Direction of public authorities. (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XVIII, § C) Sec. 50-195. - Water and sewer deposits and service charges generally. The deposit and service charges for water and sewer service shall be as set forth in the city's fee schedule. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. IX, § C; Ord. of 2006, § II; Ord. of 8-28-2006, § II) Sec. 50-196. - Special rates for extraordinary service requirements. Extraordinary circumstances, such as multiple dwelling units, industrial users, and fire protection shall be governed by special contract agreements made by the mayor and city council on recommendation of the city's engineer. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. IX, § C) Sec. 50-197. - Minimum service rates; use limitations; no free water provided. The minimum charge, as provided in the city's fee schedule, shall be made for such connection subscribed for. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only and, except for fire protection, the city shall not, under any condition, furnish water free of charge to anyone. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XII, § A) Sec. 50-198. - Minimum and additional service deposits. The deposit amounts set forth in the city fee schedule represent the minimum deposit required for the classes of water service customers within the municipal service area. In addition to that minimum, the city may, in its discretion, charge an additional deposit which shall not exceed 2½ time the customers' estimated average monthly bill during any consecutive 12-month period. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XI, § A; Ord. of 3-7-1974, § 1; Ord. of 2006, § IV; Ord. of 8-28-2006, § IV(A), (B)) Sec. 50-199. - Separate deposits required for each meter; deposit not transferrable from meter to meter. A separate water service deposit shall be required for each meter and such deposits shall be considered nontransferable. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XI, § A; Ord. of 3-7-1974, § 1; Ord. of 2006, § IV; Ord. of 8-28-2006, § IV(B)) Sec. 50-200. - Refund of deposit upon discontinuance of service; deposit transferrable to new service location. (a) All deposits will be applied against the customer's final bill when such final bill is presented by the customer for payment or before a refund is made. Customers who have deposits with the municipality may transfer the deposit to a new service location, subject to any required minimum increase in the event the amount on deposit is a pre-existing amount prior to the enactment of this section or the deposit in the city's discretion, is not sufficient to ensure payment to the city for the services provided. (b) Refunds will be made by applying the deposit to the customer's account. In the event of final billing for discontinued accounts in which the deposit exceeds the amount due, refunds shall be sent by certified mail or may be claimed in person at the city clerk's office. Any unclaimed deposits shall inure to, and be forfeited to the city; unless claimed within 90 days of final payment to the municipality. There shall not be deposit refunds in amounts less than $2.50. (Ord. of 2-7-1974, art. XI, § A; Ord. of 3-7-1974, § 1; Ord. of 2006, § IV; Ord. of 8-28-2006, § IV(C), (D)) Sec. 50-201. - Refund of deposit when service is not discontinued. Deposits may, in the city's discretion, be refunded after 24 consecutive months of service, provided that the customer has no unsatisfactory credit problems. Refunds will be made by applying the deposit to the customer's account; provided that commercial and industrial customers are not eligible for deposit refunds. In the event of final billing for discontinued accounts in which the deposit exceeds the amount due, refunds shall be sent by certified mail or may be claimed in person at the city clerk's office. Any unclaimed deposits shall inure to, and be forfeited to the city; unless claimed within 90 days of final payment to the municipality. There shall not be deposit refunds in amounts less than $2.50. (Ord. of 8-28-2006, § IV(D))

div.head: Chapter 52 - VEGETATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Plant disease, pest control and pesticides, O.C.G.A. § 2-7-1 et seq.; forest resources and other plant life, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-1 et seq.; timber harvesting and removal requirements, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-23 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 52-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Weeds means any brush, grass, vegetation, or any plant that is not regularly cut or cultivated. The term "weeds" does not include plants maintained in a garden or for agricultural purposes. A plant shall be deemed to be regularly cultivated within the meaning of this chapter if it is routinely cared for by any person or to foster, encourage, or promote its growth. (Ord. of 3-14-2006, div. I, § 1) Secs. 52-2—52-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WEEDS
Sec. 52-21. - Applicability. This article applies to owners and occupants of all residential and commercial structures and to any person who owns a vacant, developed or undeveloped property. Sec. 52-22. - Growth of weeds; vegetation. (a) The excessive, unmaintained, and uncontrolled growth of any weeds within 50 feet of the property line of a habitable dwelling or commercial building on any lot or within 50 feet of a city street or highway within the corporate limits is objectionable, unsightly, and unsanitary, and shall constitute a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any such property as defined in this Code to permit such growth to occur. (b) This section shall not be applicable to flower gardens, undeveloped property, or plots used for agricultural purposes, or the regular cultivation of any plant or other vegetation, or undeveloped property, or weeds and vegetation. (Ord. of 3-14-2006, div. I, § 8) Sec. 52-23. - Poison ivy, poison sumac. (a) Nuisance declared. Toxicodendron or toxicodendron vernix, commonly known as poison ivy and poison sumac, are hereby declared to be nuisances per se, the existence and growing of which constitutes a menace to the health of the citizens of the city and is dangerous to all persons coming in contact therewith. (b) Duty of owner, occupant. It shall be the duty of every person who owns or who is in possession of a lot upon which such plants grow to take such action as will effectively kill and destroy such poisonous plants, and it shall be unlawful for such person to fail to do so. (c) Duty, authority of city inspector. The inspector of the city is hereby authorized and directed to destroy all poison ivy or poison sumac plants growing upon the street, sidewalks or other property belonging to the city. The inspector and any employee of the city are likewise authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of destroying those plants when it is necessary to protect the public, following the procedures of this article. (Ord. of 3-14-2006, div. I, § 7) Sec. 52-24. - Public nuisance. Violation of this article is deemed as a public nuisance, which may be abated as provided by state law. Secs. 52-25—52-51. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TREES
Sec. 52-52. - General tree and shrub regulations. No person shall, without the consent of the owner in the case of a tree or shrub on private property or without permission from the city in the case of a tree or shrub on city property, do any of the following acts: (1) Climb, bark, break, peel, cut, deface, injure or destroy the whole or any part of any tree, sapling, or shrubs now growing or which may hereafter be planted by any person or by the city in any street or public place of the city, nor may any such tree be removed or cut down unless by permission of the city. (2) Secure, fasten or run any rope, wire, sign, or other device or material to, around or through a tree or shrub. (3) Permit any fire to burn where it will injure any tree or shrub. (4) Permit any toxic chemical, gas, smoke, brine, oil or other injurious substance to seep, drain, or be emptied upon any tree or shrub. (5) Place any stone, concrete, brick or any other impervious material in such a manner as to obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of the tree or shrub. (Ord. of 3-14-2006, div. I, § 16) Sec. 52-53. - Dead or diseased trees. Any dead or diseased tree or part of a tree is a nuisance per se when, by reason of such condition, natural forces may, more readily than if such tree or part thereof were live or not diseased, cause the tree or any part thereof to fall onto public ways, public sidewalks or public property, or onto private property, off the property of the owner of the tree and thereby imperil life, property or impede traffic. Upon receiving a written opinion from a qualified tree surgeon that any tree or part thereof is a nuisance per se as defined in this article, the inspector shall commence abatement proceedings pursuant to the procedure provided in article III of chapter 26. (Ord. of 3-14-2006, div. I, § 8) Sec. 52-54. - Approval of council. The city inspector shall report to the city council on each application to remove trees or shrubs. Each report shall include a recommendation of approval or disapproval of the application. The city council shall then approve or disapprove such application in writing.

div.head: Chapter 54 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of cities and counties to require certificate of public necessity and convenience as prerequisite to operation of taxicab within local government's geographical boundaries, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-25.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited in vehicles for hire; penalties; confiscation of beverages. (a) It shall be a violation of this chapter for the driver or owner of any taxicab, public conveyance, or other vehicle for hire within the corporate limits of the city to have on his person or in his automobile or other public conveyance or vehicle for hire, while engaged in such business for hire, any wine, beer, liquor, or other spirituous beverages. (b) Any person who violates this section shall be subject to penalties as set forth in section 1-11 and confiscation of such wine, beer, liquor or other spirituous beverage. If alcoholic beverages are confiscated pursuant to this section, such wine, beer, liquor, or other spirituous beverage so confiscated shall be destroyed after 30 days. (Ord. of 1-30-1950, art. II) Secs. 54-2—54-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 54-21—54-43. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSING
Sec. 54-44. - License required. Each person who engages in the business of operating one or more taxicabs in this municipality, as such term is defined herein, shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. Sec. 54-45. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Cruising means the driving of a taxicab on the streets, alleys, or public places of this city in search of or soliciting prospective passengers for hire. License means the authorization granted by the mayor and council to allow a person to engage in the business of operating taxicabs in this city. Manifest means a daily record prepared by a taxicab driver of all trips made by said driver showing time and place of origin, destination, number of passengers, and the amount of fare of each trip. Open stand means a public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere which has been designated by the chief of police as reserved exclusively for the use of taxicabs. Rate card means a card which contains the rates of fare for taxicab service and which is on clear display in each taxicab. Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, having a seating capacity of less than seven passengers, including the driver, and not operated on a fixed route. Taxicab driver's permit means the permission granted by the mayor and council to a person to drive a taxicab upon the streets of this city. Taximeter means a meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. Waiting time means the time when a taxicab is not in motion from the time of arrival at the point of origin of a trip to the time of commencement of such trip. Sec. 54-46. - Application for license. (a) Application for a license under this article shall be made as provided in chapter 12, except that such application shall contain the following additional information: (1) The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to said judgments; (2) The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; (3) Any facts that the applicant believes tend to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of a license; (4) The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed depots and terminals; and (5) The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the applicant. (b) All applicants shall also submit to a background check of their criminal history through the Georgia Crime Information Center and of their driving history with the Georgia Department of Driver Services. Sec. 54-47. - License fee; bond. Each applicant for a licenses hereunder shall pay a nonrefundable administrative fee. In addition, the annual business license fee for each person engaged in the business of operating taxicabs in the city shall be the amount established by resolution of the city. The city council may in its discretion require a surety bond as a prerequisite to issuance of a license under this article, and may allow the applicant to file, in lieu of a bond, a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. Sec. 54-48. - Taxicab driver's license and permit. (a) No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be so driven, and no taxicabs licensed under the provisions of this article shall be driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of said taxicab shall have first obtained and shall have then in force a valid motor vehicle driver's license, issued by the state, and a valid taxicab driver's permit issued by the city as provided herein. (b) An application for a taxicab driver's permit shall be in writing, addressed to the mayor and council, and filed with the city clerk; and such application shall be verified under oath and shall contain the following information: (1) The names and addresses of four residents of the city who have known the applicant and who will vouch for the sobriety, honesty, and general good character of the applicant; (2) The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; (3) The educational background of the applicant; and (4) A concise history of his employment. (5) Certified copies of the driver's criminal history through the Georgia Crime Information Center and his driving history with the Georgia Department of Driver Services. If the driver is unable to obtain these records, he or she shall execute the necessary forms or releases to allow the city to obtain them. (c) Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician certifying that, in his opinion, the applicant is not afflicted with any disease or infirmity which might make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver, and a permit fee in the amount established by the city council. Sec. 54-49. - Inspections. (a) No taxicab shall be permitted to be used or operated in this municipality until such vehicle has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined under the supervision of the chief of police and has been found to comply with such reasonable rules and regulations respecting safety and sanitation as may be prescribed by said chief of police. These rules and regulations shall be promulgated to ensure safe and sanitary transportation and shall specify such equipment and regulatory devices as the chief of police shall deem necessary therefor. (b) When it has been determined that a vehicle has met the standards established by the chief of police, a certificate to that effect shall be issued, which certificate shall also state the authorized seating capacity of said vehicle. Such certificate may be withdrawn and the vehicle relating thereto suspended from operation at any time by the chief of police if such vehicle is found to be unsafe or not in compliance with any regulations promulgated by such officer or imposed by this section. (c) Periodic inspections of taxicabs shall be made at such intervals as shall be established by the chief of police to ensure that such vehicles are kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use. Sec. 54-50. - Taximeters. (a) All taxicabs operating in this municipality shall be equipped with taximeters fastened in front of the passengers, visible to them at all times of day and night; and, after sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. Said taximeter shall be operated mechanically by a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or from one of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached driving mechanism, and each shall be sealed at all points and connections which, if manipulated, would affect a correct reading and recording. (b) Each taximeter shall have thereon a flag to denote when the vehicle is employed and when it is not employed; and it shall be the duty of the driver to throw the flag of such taximeter into a nonrecording position at the termination of each trip. (c) The taximeters shall be subject to inspection from time to time by the police department. Any inspector or other officer of said department is authorized, either on complaint of any person or without such complaint, to inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the person operating said taxicab to cease operation. Thereupon, said taxicab shall be kept off the public roads until the taximeter is repaired. Sec. 54-51. - Receipts. The driver of any taxicab shall, upon request by the passenger, render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt, on which shall be the name of the owner, license number of motor number, amount of the meter reading or charges, and the date of the transaction. Sec. 54-52. - Solicitation, acceptance, and discharge of passenger. (a) No driver shall solicit passengers for a taxicab except when sitting in the driver's compartment of such taxicab or while standing immediately adjacent to the curbside thereof. The driver of any taxicab shall remain in the driver's compartment or immediately adjacent to his vehicle at all times when such vehicle is upon the public street, except that, when necessary, a driver may be absent from his taxicab for not more than ten consecutive minutes, and provided further that nothing herein contained shall be held to prohibit any driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of such vehicle. (b) No driver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice, or by sign, or in any manner annoy any person or obstruct the movement of any person, or follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage. (c) Drivers of taxicabs shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall pull up to the right-hand sidewalk as nearly as possible or, in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets where passengers may be discharged at either the right- or left-hand sidewalk or side of the roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. (d) No driver shall cruise in search of passengers except in such areas and at such times as shall be designated by the chief of police. Such areas and times shall only be designated when said officer finds that taxicab cruising would not congest traffic or be dangerous to pedestrians and other vehicles. (e) No driver, owner, or operator shall solicit passengers at the terminal of any other common carrier, nor at any intermediate points along any established route of any other common carrier. (f) No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in said taxicab, unless the persons first employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of additional passengers. No charge shall be made for an additional passenger except when the said additional passenger rides beyond the previous passenger's destination and then only for the additional distance so traveled.

div.head: Chapter 56 - ZONING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Downtown development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq.; municipal business improvement districts, O.C.G.A. § 36-43-1 et seq.; redevelopment authority of municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-44-1; city and county development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; county and municipal urban development, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; city and county zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning and service delivery by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 56-1. - Use of substandard lots of record. (a) No permit for the use of or construction on any lot which is smaller in total area than the minimum size for the district within which it is located shall be issued unless said lot was legally and properly recorded as a building lot prior to the adoption of a zoning ordinance within the city. Said lots in residential districts shall be used only for single-family residential (R-1) purposes. Permits for the use of or construction on any such lot shall be considered a conditional use and must meet all other requirements of the district in which it is located. The city council shall have the authority to grant or deny any permit for the use of or construction on any such lot upon submission of building plans by the lot owner that demonstrates compliance with the zoning requirements of the district in which the property is located. (b) Building plans shall include a plat of the lot and proposed structure to show the location of the proposed structure on the lot, the dimensions of the proposed structure, as well as conformity with appropriate set back distances and other zoning requirements. The plans shall also include an architectural drawing of the exterior of the proposed structure with front, rear, and side views. Upon review of the building plans, the city council, in its discretion, may allow zoning exceptions or variations as necessitated by the dimensions of the lot and/or the lot's proximity to neighboring property lines and structures. The city council may also require any construction to include appropriate buffers or other reasonable measures deemed appropriate to prevent an adverse affect of construction on neighboring property owners. If construction is approved on any such lot, such construction shall be completed within one year from the time approval is granted by the city council. (c) Simultaneously upon submission of building plans, the petitioner shall notify all surrounding property owners of the proposed construction by certified mail, return receipt requested, so that these owners may voice any concerns at a public hearing to be held on the proposed conditional use. The city council shall not schedule a public hearing on construction on any such lot until it receives written confirmation from the petitioner that all neighboring property owners were sent notice of the construction and building plans at least ten days prior to any scheduled public hearing. All submissions by a petition to the city shall be made through the city clerk's office. The clerk shall forward any building plans or corresponding materials received to the mayor and council for review, prior to any related public hearing and final consideration of the requested permit for a conditional use. (Ord. of 1-25-2006, § Two) Sec. 56-2. - Definitions. (a) For the purpose of interpreting this chapter, the term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel." The term "building" includes the term "structure." The term "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, includes the term "intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied." The term "maps," "zoning maps," or "Buchanan Zoning Map" means the "Official Zoning Map, Buchanan, Georgia." (b) Except as specifically defined herein all words used in this chapter shall carry their customary meaning as defined by a standard dictionary. Accessory use means a use customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or building and located on the same lot with such principal use or building. Alley means a minor way used for service access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting a street. Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or by walls and intended for shelter, housing, or enclosure of persons, animals, or chattels. Building, accessory, means a building subordinate or supplemental to the main building on a lot and used for purposes customarily incidental to that of a main or principal building and located on the same lot therewith. Building, principal, means a building in which is conducted the main use of the lot on which said building is located. Conditional use means a use not ordinarily permitted but which may be permitted upon the imposition of conditions related to the promotion of the public health, safety, morals or general welfare and designed to minimize the negative impact on surrounding lands. Such conditions may include, but are not limited to, restrictions on land use; height, setback and other non-use requirements; physical improvements to the property and infrastructure serving the property. A conditional use must be approved in the same manner as a rezoning request prior to the issuance of a permit. Conditional zoning means the imposition of conditions in the grant of a rezoning application which are in addition to or different from the regulations set forth in this chapter and which are related to the promotion of the public health, safety, morals or general welfare and designed to minimize the negative impact on surrounding lands. Such conditions may include, but are not limited to, restrictions on land use, height, setbacks and other non-use requirements, physical improvements to the property and infrastructure serving the property. Customary agricultural use means the raising of soil crops and livestock in a customary manner on tracts of land at least ten acres in size and shall include all associated activities. Retail selling of products raised on the premises shall be considered a permissible activity provided that space necessary for the parking of customers' vehicles shall be provided off the public rights-of-way. Dwelling means a building designed, arranged, or used for permanent living quarters for one or more persons. Dwelling unit means a building, or portion thereof, providing complete living facilities for one family. Family means one or more persons occupying a dwelling and living as a single housekeeping unit. Hazardous waste includes any engagement in the disposal of any biomedical waste, contaminant, designated hazardous waste, hazardous chemical substance or mixture, hazardous constituent, hazardous waste, municipal solid waste, oil, pesticide, solid waste, or special solid waste. The term "hazardous waste" also includes the construction, installation, operation, or alteration of any composting facility, land disposal facility, landfill, municipal solid waste disposal facility, municipal solid waste landfill, private sanitary landfill, or incinerators. This shall further include the construction, installation, operation, or alteration of any chemical manufacturing plants, hazardous waste facilities, recycling plants, fertilizer plants or fertilizer deposit areas (covering an area in excess of one acre) or any use that involves the ponding or pooling of liquid industrial waste or liquid chemicals which, in their mixed or unmixed state, are suspected or proven to cause danger to the environment or to human health. Tanneries, glue factories, use of coal boilers or burners for commercial or industrial purposes, automobile or motorcycle race tracks, automobile or motorcycle practice tracks, airports, heliports and any industrial or commercial use that may emit injurious or obnoxious noises, vibrations, smoke, dust, fumes, gas or odors shall also be also be included in this definition. Home occupation means any use customarily conducted within the principal dwelling and carried on by the occupant thereof; provided that, such use shall not occupy more than 30 percent of the heated floor space; provided further, that such use is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling as a residence and does not change the character thereof or reveal from the exterior that the dwelling is being used in part for other than a residence; provided further, that there is no display, no stock in trade, no commodity sold on the premises, and no mechanical equipment used except such as is commonly used for purely domestic household purposes. Such permissible occupations include, in general, such personal services such as are furnished by a musician, artist, seamstress, cook, or laundress, but shall not include such uses as barbershops, beauty parlors, tea rooms, tourist homes, animal hospitals, professional offices, or wholesale, retail or manufacturing businesses. Junk yard means any such use involving the storage or disassembly of wrecked automobiles, trucks, or other vehicles; storage, baling or otherwise dealing in bones, animal hides, scrap metal, used paper, used cloth, used plumbing fixtures and used brick, wood, or other building materials. Such uses shall be considered junk yards whether or not all or part of such operations are conducted inside a building or in conjunction with, addition to, or accessory to, other uses of the premises. Lot means a portion or parcel of land devoted to a common use or occupied by a building or group of buildings devoted to a common use, together with the customary accessories and open spaces belonging to the same. Lot, depth of, means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines, measured in the general direction of the side lot lines. Lot, width of, means the distance between side lot lines measured at the building line. Manufactured home means a detached, single-family dwelling unit designed for long-term occupancy and constructed in one of more units with wheels for movement (whether or not such wheels are later removed) and which has plumbing and electrical connections provided for attachment to outside systems, whether or not such unit is subsequently installed on a permanent foundation or other internal or external changes are made. Manufactured home park means a parcel of land which has been planned and improved for the placement of manufactured homes for nontransient use. Mobile home means a transportable, factory-built home designed to be used as year around residential dwelling and built prior to the enactment of the Federal Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, which became effective June 15, 1976. Mobile Homes are not permitted uses in any district. Nonconforming use means a building, structure, or use of land existing at the time of enactment of this chapter, and which does not conform to the regulations of the district in which it was located. Roominghouse or boardinghouse means a dwelling, other than a hotel or lodginghouse, where meals or housing accommodations for three or more persons are provided for hire. Sign, business, means an attached or free-standing structure which directs attention to a business or profession conducted on the premises. Sign, outdoor advertising, means a structural poster panel or painted sign, either free-standing or attached to the outside of a building, for the purpose of conveying information, knowledge, or ideas to the public about a subject either related or unrelated to the premises upon which it is located. Single-family dwelling means a building designed for or occupied exclusively by one family. Site built housing means a single family dwelling constructed from materials not fabricated as an completed dwelling unit before arriving for on-site construction. Street means a public or private way which affords the principal means to access to abutting properties. Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires location on the ground, or attachment to something having location on the ground. Yard means a space on the same lot with a principal building open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings, or structures from ground to sky except where encroachments and accessory buildings are expressly permitted. Yard, front, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot, and situated between the street and the front lines of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Yard, rear, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and situated between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Yard, side, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, situated between the building and the side lot line of the lot and extending from the front yard to the rear yard. Any side lot line not a rear line or a front line shall be deemed a side line. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, §§ 3.1, 3.2) Secs. 56-3—56-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS
Sec. 56-26. - Division into districts. For the purpose of this chapter, the city is divided into eight districts designated as follows:
(Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 4.1) Sec. 56-27. - District boundaries. The boundaries of each district are shown on a map entitled "Official Zoning Map, Buchanan, Georgia," adopted by the city council and certified by the city clerk, as amended from time to time. Said map and all explanatory matter thereon accompanies and is hereby made a part of this chapter. Said map shall be retained in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 4.2) Sec. 56-28. - Rules for determining boundaries. Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any of the aforesaid districts as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply: (1) Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the center lines of streets or highways, street lines, or right-of-way lines, such center lines, street lines, or highway right-of-way lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. (2) Where district boundaries are so indicated that they approximately follow lot lines, such lot lines shall be construed to be said boundaries. (3) Where district boundaries are so indicated that they are approximately parallel to the center lines of streets, highways, or railroads, or rights-of-way of same, such district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel thereto and distance therefrom as indicated on the zoning map. If no distance is given, such dimension shall be determined by the use of the scale shown on said zoning map. (4) Where a district boundary line, as appearing on the zoning map, divides a lot in single ownership at the time of this enactment, the district requirements for the least restricted portion of such lot shall be deemed to apply to the whole thereof, provided that such extensions shall not include any part of such a lot more than 35 feet beyond the district boundary line. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 4.3) Secs. 56-29—56-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS
Sec. 56-51. - Use. No building, structure, or land shall hereafter be used or occupied, and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or structurally altered unless in conformity with all of the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.1) Sec. 56-52. - Height and density. No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or altered: (1) To exceed the height limits; (2) To accommodate or house a greater number of families or occupy a smaller lot area per family; or (3) To have narrower or smaller rear yards, front yards, side yards, or other open spaces than are herein required or specified; or in any other manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.2) Sec. 56-53. - Yard service to one building. No part of a yard, or other open space, or off-street parking or loading space required about, or in connection with, any building for the purpose of complying with this chapter, shall be included as part of a yard, open space, or off-street parking or loading space similarly required for any other building. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.3) Sec. 56-54. - Only one principal building. Every building or structure hereafter erected shall be located on a lot or tract as defined herein; and there shall not be more than one principal building on one lot, plus its accessory buildings, except as provided in section 56-174. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.4) Sec. 56-55. - Reduction of lot area. No lot, even though it may consist of one or more adjacent lots of record, shall be reduced in size so that the lot width or depth, front, side or rear yard, lot area per family, or other requirements of this chapter, are not maintained. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for public purposes. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.5) Sec. 56-56. - Street frontage. No principal building shall be erected on any lot which does not have immediate frontage on at least one street for a distance of not less than 25 feet. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.6) Sec. 56-57. - Corner and double-frontage lots. On lots having frontage on more than one street in residential districts, the minimum front yard shall be provided for each street in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.7) Sec. 56-58. - Inspection of required buffers. In the event a screen, wall, fence, planted dividing strip, or any other type of buffer is required by this chapter for any use, such screen, wall, etc., will be subjected to periodic inspections by the building inspector to determine that such required walls, fences, etc., are being properly maintained. Failure to maintain such required walls, fences, etc., to an acceptable standard may be deemed a violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 5.8) Secs. 56-59—56-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 56-81. - Continuance of a nonconforming use. The lawful use of any building or structure or land existing at the time of the enactment of or subsequent amendment to this section may be continued subject to the restrictions contained in this section even though such use does not conform with the provisions of this section except that the nonconforming structure or use shall not be: (1) Changed to another nonconforming use. (2) Torn down and rebuilt as a nonconforming use. (3) Extended or enlarged except in conformity with this section. (4) Reestablished after vacancy or discontinuance for one year. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.1) Sec. 56-82. - Americans with Disabilities Act compliance. All new construction shall require compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Further information on the ADA can be obtained from the city. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.2) Sec. 56-83. - Newly annexed territory. All territory which may hereafter be annexed to the city may be classified in the district according to the use contemplated by the owner, subject to the approval of the city council. If the owners do not specify a zoning district preference, then said newly annexed territory shall be classified in an R-1 Residential District until otherwise classified by amendment to this chapter, as provided herein. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.3) Sec. 56-84. - Off-street automobile parking and storage. Except in the C-1, Central Business District, off-street automobile parking or storage space shall be provided on every lot on which any of the following uses are hereafter established. Such automobile parking or storage space shall be provided with vehicular access to a street or alley and shall be equal in area to at least the minimum requirements for the specific use as set forth below. Each off-street parking space shall be at least eight feet, six inches wide, and 18 feet deep. (1) If the required automobile parking or storage space cannot be provided on the same lot on which the principal use is located, the board of appeals may permit such space to be provided on other off-street property, provided such space is within 500 feet of such principal use. Such space shall be associated with the permitted use and shall not thereafter be reduced or encroached upon in any manner. (2) All off-street automobile parking and storage space in residential districts shall be so arranged that vehicles will not be required to back onto a public street, road, or highway when leaving the premises. (3) Minimum requirements for parking/storage are as follows:
(Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.4) Sec. 56-85. - Off-street loading and unloading space. Every building or structure used for business, trade or industry shall provide space as indicated herein for the loading and unloading of vehicles off the street or public alley. Such space shall have access to an alley or if there is no alley, to a street. Such space shall have at least 14 feet of vertical clearance. Such space shall be so arranged that no vehicle is required to back onto a public street, road, or highway in order to leave the premises. (1) Retail business. One space, ten feet by 25 feet, for each 3,000 square feet of floor area or any part thereof. (2) Wholesale and industry. One space, ten feet by 50 feet, for each 10,000 square feet of floor area or any part thereof. (3) Bus and truck terminals. Sufficient space to accommodate the maximum number of buses or trucks to be stored or to be loaded or unloaded at the terminal at any one time. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.5) Sec. 56-86. - Required buffers. (a) A buffer area shall be defined as that portion of a lot set aside for open space and/or visual screening purpose, pursuant to applicable provisions of this chapter, to separate different use districts and/or uses on one property from uses on another property of the same use district or a different use district. The required buffer may consist of either fencing or natural plantings. Said fence buffer shall be at least six feet in height and shall be constructed of masonry, ventilated redwood, cedar, chainlink fence with natural planting, or other similar materials. Said fencing will sufficiently block uses in one zone from uses in another. If natural plantings are used instead of or in addition to fencing, said planting shall be of a type and variety which shall provide adequate visual screening and shall be at a height of six feet within a three year period. Maintenance of natural plantings shall follow the land on which it is located. (b) An adequate buffer strip of at least 20 feet in width shall be required and maintained between an area zoned as R-1 and any area zoned as either R-2 or R-3. Such buffer shall be constructed and/or maintained by the owner of the land zoned R-2 or R-3. (c) Said buffer area may not be used for any parking or for the erection of any permanent structure thereon. However, a buffer area may be used for vehicular access and utility easements and for drainage improvements required by the city based upon competent engineering studies. (d) Except as provided herein, the natural topography of the land shall be preserved and natural growth shall not be disturbed beyond that which is necessary to prevent a nuisance, or to thin such natural growth when too dense for normal growth, or to remove diseased, misshapen, or dangerous and decayed timbers. However, a slope easement may be cleared and graded where required to prevent soil erosion upon approval of the city building inspector. (e) An adequate buffer strip of fencing and natural plantings of at least 20 feet in width shall be required and maintained between any area zoned commercial C-1 and any area zoned residential, either R-1, R-2, or R-3. Such buffer shall be constructed and/or maintained by the owner of the land zoned as commercial. (f) An adequate buffer strip of fencing and natural plantings of at least 30 feet in width shall be required and maintained between any area zoned industrial IND-G and any area zoned residential, either R-1, R-2, R-3, or commercial C-1. Such buffer shall be constructed and/or maintained by the owner of the land zoned as industrial. (g) Prohibited plants. The following plants shall not be installed as landscape material for buffers: (1) Kudzu (Pueraria lobata); and (2) Popcorn or Chinese tallow tree (sapium sebiferum). (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.6) Sec. 56-87. - Site distance. On a corner lot in a residential area, no fence, wall or structure, planting or other foliage shall be erected or established between a height of two feet and 12 feet within 25 feet of the intersection. This measure shall begin at the center of the intersection. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.7) Sec. 56-88. - Satellite receiving dish antenna. (a) Satellite receiving dish antennas shall be allowed in all zoning districts. (b) Antennas will be erected only in rear yard and the setback requirements from the property lines will be the same as those required of an accessory building. (c) In all zoning districts, antennas will be so placed as not to create a hazard to traffic or public utilities. (d) A property owner who has in place a nonconforming antenna at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may continue to maintain the antenna. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.8) Sec. 56-89. - Variances. (a) Where the mayor and council find that strict compliance with the provisions of this chapter would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, the mayor and council may, upon application from the property owner, grant a variance from the terms of this chapter so that the spirit and intent of this chapter shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted in such individual case of unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the mayor and council that all of the following conditions exist: (1) There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape or topography. (2) The application of this section to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship. (3) Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved. (4) Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this section; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this section. (b) Upon application by a property owner for a variance from the terms of this section, the mayor and council shall fix a date for a public hearing upon said request for variance. (1) Said hearing shall be scheduled for a date no more than 60 days from the date of said application for variance. (2) Notice of said hearing on said request for a variance shall be advertised for two consecutive weeks in the newspaper in which the city regularly publishes its public notices, the first date of such publication being at least 15 days but no more than 45 days prior to the date of said public hearing. (3) The applicant for said variance shall also give actual notice of said request for variance and the public hearing thereon to all property owners adjoining the property for which said variance is requested. Said notice shall be given to the adjoining property owners either in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of said adjoining property owner. Said actual notice must be given no later than ten days prior to the date of said scheduled public hearing. (4) The notice required herein to be published and to be served upon adjacent property owners shall contain the following information: a. Name and address of the applicant. b. Address and location of the property for which the variance is sought. c. Current zoning of the property for which the variance is sought. d. The variance requested and the reason for the requested variance. e. The date, time and place of the public hearing on said requested variance. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.9) Sec. 56-90. - Minimum housing size. Within the city all single-family housing shall have a minimum of 980 square feet of living space. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 6.10) Secs. 56-91—56-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - USE REQUIREMENTS BY DISTRICTS
Sec. 56-116. - R-1 Residential District. (a) Permitted uses. Within an R-1 Residential District, the following uses shall be permitted: (1) Single-family dwellings on one-half acre (21,780 square foot) lots or minimum square footage as required by the health department. (2) Accessory buildings provided such shall be permitted only in a rear yard and shall not be less than five feet from any property line. (3) Swimming pool with a minimum four-foot-high fence surrounding the pool area. (4) Manufactured housing/mobile homes shall not be permitted. (b) Conditional uses. The following are conditional uses: (1) Churches and similar places of worship and their customary related uses provided that: a. They are provided with adequate, paved off-street parking. b. Provisions for a planted buffer strip along adjoining property lines. (2) Public and private schools offering general education courses. (3) Municipal, county, state, federal, and other public uses, including parks and playgrounds. (4) Nursery schools and kindergartens, provided that they shall have at least 35 square feet of indoor space provided for each child and at least 100 square feet of play area per child in the outdoor play area; and that the outdoor play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of six feet; and provided that the principal building of such use shall meet all the yard requirements of the R-1 Residential District. (5) Customary agricultural operations conducted on not less than ten acres of land with buildings used in connection with any animals no closer than 200 feet to any property line. (6) Home occupations. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 7.1) Sec. 56-117. - R-2 Multifamily Residential District. (a) Permitted uses. Within an R-2 Residential District, the following uses shall be permitted: (1) Two-family dwellings, multifamily dwellings and apartment buildings on 15,000 square foot lots. Apartment buildings (five or more units per building) sites must have 100 feet frontage on public street. Total building area is limited to 25 percent of site area. Such development shall be connected to the public sewer if available. If public sewer is not available, requirements of the health department shall be strictly adhered to with a letter from the health department stating specific conditions for such development. Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided on site for each dwelling unit, except in the case of low-rent public housing which shall provide 1½ parking spaces. Each dwelling unit shall have separate bath/toilet and kitchen/dining areas. Each dwelling unit shall contain a minimum of: a. 360 square feet: Efficiency apartments. b. 500 square feet: One bedroom units. c. 620 square feet: Two bedroom units. d. 730 square feet: Three bedroom units. e. 850 square feet: Four bedroom units. (2) Buildings should be spaced at least 20 feet apart. The front of one building must not face the rear of another building on the site. (3) Accessory buildings, provided such shall be permitted only in a rear yard and shall not be less than five feet from any property line. (4) Swimming pool with a minimum four-foot-high fence surrounding the pool area. (b) Conditional uses. The following are conditional uses: (1) Single-family housing on 15,000 square foot lots or the minimum required by the health department. (Refer to compatibility standards.) (2) Manufactured housing on 15,000 square foot lots. (Manufactured housing parks shall not be allowed.) (Refer to compatibility standards.) (3) Churches and similar places of worship and their customary related uses provided that: a. They are provided with adequate, paved off-street parking. b. Provisions for a planted buffer strip along adjoining property lines. (4) Public and private schools offering general education courses. (5) Municipal, county, state, federal, and other public uses, including parks and playgrounds. (6) Nursery schools and kindergartens provided that they shall have at least 35 square feet of indoor space provided for each child and at least 100 square feet of play area per child in the outdoor play area; and that the outdoor play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of six feet; and provided that the principal building of such use shall meet all the lot requirements of the R-1 Residential District. (7) Customary agricultural operations conducted on not less than ten acres of land with buildings used in connection with any animals no closer than 200 feet to any property line. (8) Home occupations. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 7.2) Sec. 56-118. - R-3 Residential District. (a) Permitted uses. Within an R-3 Residential District, the following uses shall be permitted: (1) Individual manufactured housing on individual lots with a minimum one-half acre (21,780 square foot) lot, provided they meet all requirements set forth in the city manufactured housing ordinance. (2) Mobile home and manufactured housing parks, customary accessory uses, but not to include the sale of or service to mobile homes and manufactured housing, provided they meet the requirements set forth in the city manufactured housing ordinance. (3) Accessory buildings, provided such shall be permitted only in a rear yard and shall not be less than five feet from any property line. (4) Swimming pool with a minimum four-foot-high fence surrounding the pool area. (5) Conventional site built housing shall not be allowed. (b) Conditional uses. The following are conditional uses: (1) Churches and similar places of worship and their customary related uses provided that: a. They are provided with adequate, paved, off-street parking. b. Provisions for a planted buffer strip along adjoining property lines. (2) Public and private schools offering general education courses. (3) Municipal, county, state, federal, and other public uses, including parks and playgrounds. (4) Nursery schools and kindergartens, provided that they shall have at least 35 square feet of indoor space provided for each child and at least 100 square feet of play area per child in the outdoor play area; and that the outdoor play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of six feet; and provided that the principal building of such use shall meet all the yard requirements of the R-1 Residential District. (5) Tourist homes; roominghouses and boardinghouses. (6) Public and private clubs. (7) Customary agricultural operations shall be conducted on not less than ten acres of land with no building used in connection with any animals closer than 200 feet to any property line. (8) Home occupations. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 7.3) Sec. 56-119. - C-1 Central Business District. (a) Permitted uses. Within the C-1 Central Business District, the following uses shall be permitted: (1) Art and antique stores. (2) Banks. (3) Health clubs, spas, and other similar activities. (4) Clothing, shoe, millinery, dry goods and notion stores. (5) Drugstores. (6) Garden supply stores. (7) Grocery stores (8) Furniture and home furnishings stores. (9) Florist and gift shops. (10) Hardware and paint stores. (11) Barbershops and beauty shops. (12) Cafes, grills, lunch counters, and restaurants (not including restaurants with drive through windows). (13) Attached outdoor advertising signs and business signs (as permitted under the sign ordinance portion of this chapter.) (14) Retail businesses and service establishments of like, similar, of compatible use to those currently existing within this zoning district. (15) Any new like and similar uses not mentioned shall be considered under the guidelines established for evaluating conditional uses. Such new uses shall then be added as either a permitted or conditional use for this zoning district. (b) Conditional uses. The following are conditional uses: (1) Automobile service stations, provided that all structures and buildings, except principal use signs, and including storage tanks, shall be placed not less than 25 feet from any side or rear property lines except where such side or rear property lines abut a street, in which case the setback shall be that required from such streets measured from the right-of-way. All buildings or structures including gas pumps and storage tanks, except principal use signs, shall comply with the setback requirements of any abutting street. If on a corner lot, the means of ingress and egress shall be provided not less than 15 feet from the intersection of street lines. Ingress and egress shall be arranged and designed so as to minimize the interference with the flow of traffic, either vehicular or pedestrian. (2) Appliance stores, including repairs and services. (3) Automobile parking lots and garages. (4) Auction houses. (5) Bus terminals. (6) Newspaper offices and print shops. (7) Theater, but not including drive-in theaters. (8) Wholesaling establishments of like, similar, or compatible use to those currently existing within this zoning district. (9) Public utility structures and buildings, including electric and natural gas substations, telephone exchanges, and similar structures for the storage of supplies, equipment, or service operations when properly screened. (10) Churches and similar places of worship and their customary related uses provided that: a. They are provided with adequate, paved off-street parking. b. Provisions for a planted buffer strip along adjoining property lines. (11) Public and private schools offering general education courses. (12) Municipal, county, state, federal, and other public uses, including parks and playgrounds. (13) Nursery schools and kindergartens, provided that they shall have at least 35 square feet of indoor space provided for each child and at least 100 square feet of play area per child in the outdoor play area; and that the outdoor play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of six feet; and provided that the principal building of such use shall meet all the yard requirements of the R-1 Residential District. (14) Veterinary hospitals, treating small animals only, provided any structure or outside area used for such purposes shall be a minimum of 100 feet from any residential district. (15) Golf, swimming, tennis, or country clubs, public and private community clubs or associations, athletic fields, parks and recreational areas. The size and intensity of the proposed use as it relates to adjacent land uses shall be determining factor. (16) Hotels and motels. (17) Plant nurseries. (18) Private clubs, and fraternal order of lodges. (19) Professional and business offices, including banks and financial institutions. (20) Variety stores. (21) Hospitals, clinics, and convalescent or nursing homes. (22) Temporary uses including sale of Christmas trees, carnivals, church bazaars, and sale of seasonal fruits and vegetables from roadside stands, but such use is not be to permitted for a period to exceed two months in any calendar year. (23) Dry cleaning and laundry establishments, provided that such operation is or local service only and no work is done on the premises for other similar establishments or pickup stations. (24) Shopping centers. The following guidelines govern construction of shopping centers: a. Shopping centers should not exceed 60,000 square feet in gross floor area. b. Leading tenants shall be a grocery store or a drug store; neither shall exceed 40,000 square feet in gross floor area. c. Shopping centers shall be located along arterial, collector or secondary streets. d. Required green space and open space buffers as required by this chapter. (25) Colleges, public and private schools, and libraries. (26) Group personal care homes and supportive living homes. (27) Recreational, amusement, or entertainment facilities. (28) Tent revivals. (29) Funeral homes. (30) Used car sales lot; provided, however, that such lot shall not maintain for sale more than ten cars at any one time, and provided further that said used car sales lot is located on an arterial street. (31) Self-serve car washing facilities, provided they are located on an arterial street. (32) Bed and breakfast inns; provided all parking can be maintained on the lot and not along collector or secondary streets. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 7.4) Sec. 56-120. - IND-G general industrial district. Within an IND-G General Industrial District, the following uses shall be permitted: (1) Communication towers, provided that the amount of land associated with this use be equal to or greater than the height of the tower length measured from the base of the tower and proceeding in any direction. (2) Any industry which does not cause injurious or obnoxious noise, vibrations, smoke, gas fumes, odor, dust, fire hazard, or other objectionable conditions. This shall not include any hazardous waste as defined by this chapter. (3) Truck terminals. (4) Wholesaling and warehousing. (5) Any retail or service establishment dependent upon or closely related to industry. (6) Storage yards, including building materials and lumber yards, but not junk yards or automobile junk yards, provided any such use is screened from view by a solid wall, planted screen or similar opaque partition at least six feet in height. Such partition shall comply with all setback requirements of this district. (7) Automobile service stations, provided that all structures and buildings, except principal use signs, and including storage tanks shall be placed not less than 25 feet from any side or rear property lines except where such side or rear property lines abut a street, in which case the setback shall be that required from such streets measured from the right-of-way. All buildings or structures including gas pumps and storage tanks, except principal use signs, shall comply with the setback requirements of any abutting street. If on a corner lot, the means of ingress and egress shall be provided not less than 15 feet from the intersection of street lines. Ingress and egress shall be arranged and designed so as to minimize the interference with the flow of traffic, either vehicular or pedestrian. (8) Signs, including outdoor advertising, incidental or accessory advertising, and business signs. (9) Other like and similar uses considering traffic generation, hours of operation, and other businesses within in this zone. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 7.5) Secs. 56-121—56-145. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - AREA, YARD, AND HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 56-146. - Table showing requirements. The table below outlines the area, yard, and height requirements.
NOTE: (1) Minimum front yard shall be measured form the street ROW to the front line of the principal structure. Minimum side/rear yard shall be measured from the street ROW or lot lie to the side/rear line of the principal structure. (2) When abutting a residential district, a side yard of at least 20 feet in width shall be provided. (3) When abutting a street or road, a side yard of at least 50 feet shall be provided. (4) When abutting a residential district, a rear yard of at least 20 feet in depth shall be provided. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, art. VIII) Secs. 56-147—56-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - EXCEPTIONS AND MODIFICATIONS
Sec. 56-171. - Lots of record. (a) Single lots. Where the owner of a lot at the time of the adoption of this chapter or his successor in title thereto does not own sufficient land to enable him to conform to the dimensional requirements of this chapter, such lot may be used as a building site for a single-family residence in a district where residences are permitted. (b) Adjoining lots. If two or more adjoining lots with continuous frontage are in a single ownership at any time after the adoption of this chapter and such lots individually are too small to meet the yard, width, and area requirements of the district in which they are located, such groups of lots shall be considered as a single lot or several lots of minimum permitted size and the lot or lots in one ownership shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 9.1) Sec. 56-172. - Height limits. The height limitations of this chapter shall not apply to church spires, belfries, cupolas and domes not intended for human occupancy; monuments, water towers, observation towers, transmission towers, chimneys, smokestacks, conveyors, flag poles, radio towers, television towers, masts, aerials and similar structures. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 9.2) Sec. 56-173. - Group projects. A group project (including, but not limited to, residential, commercial, industrial, educational, medical, religious, or civic uses) of two or more buildings to be constructed on a plot of land at least two acres not subdivided into customary streets and lots, and which will not be so subdivided, may be constructed provided: (1) Such uses are limited to those permitted within the district in which the project is located. (2) The overall intensity of land use is no higher, and the standard of open space is no lower than that permitted on the district in which the project is located. (3) The distance of every building from the nearest property line shall meet the front yard setback and side yard requirements of the district in which the project is located. (4) The building heights do not exceed the height limits permitted in the district in which the project is located. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 9.3) Sec. 56-174. - Conditional use requirements. Any use which may be authorized by a conditional use permit may be approved by the city only if: (1) A proper application has been filed in accordance with the requirements of the city. (2) The applicant is in compliance with the particular conditions for the proposed conditional use that are required by this chapter (lot size, minimum square footage, etc.). (3) The applicant is in compliance with conditions imposed by the city for the purpose of reducing the harmful effects of the use on surrounding uses and ensuring compatibility with surrounding uses. (4) The city determines that the benefits of and need for the proposed conditional use are greater than any possible depreciating effects and damages to the neighboring properties. (5) An application for a conditional use which has been denied shall not be resubmitted for a period of 12 months. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 9.4) Secs. 56-175—56-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - MANUFACTURED HOUSING
Sec. 56-201. - Manufactured housing requirements. Any dwelling that is classified as a manufactured home by the definitions stated in this chapter shall be subject to the following provisions of this chapter: (1) A location decal application shall be required to be filed for a manufactured home in the office of the tax commissioner annually for each manufactured home that is henceforth located on an individual lot, in a manufactured home park or subdivision in the city. (2) All manufactured housing shall have an insignia (decal) issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and shall be constructed in conformity with the requirements of the Federal Manufactured Housing and Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, which became effective on June 15, 1976. Said unit shall contain not less than 980 square feet. (3) All manufactured home installations must meet manufacturer's specifications and/or the specifications of this chapter, whichever is stricter, before permanent utilities may be installed. Utility connections prior to the final inspection of the installation will be considered temporary and will be approved only when arrangements for complete installations have been made. (4) Any manufactured home, whether on an individual lot or in a manufactured home subdivision, shall be required to be underpinned prior to occupancy; provided however, relocated manufactured homes shall have 30 days from the date a relocation permit is obtained to underpin said manufactured home in accordance with this section. a. The underpinning shall consist of one of the following: masonry, vinyl siding/panels or aluminum siding/panels, or such other material as may be approved by the zoning administrator prior to installation. b. The following types of materials are not permitted to be used, including, but not limited to: tin, wood (unless of natural decay resistance type such as cedar), plastic sheeting or gypsum board (black board). c. The underpinning must be adequately secured to the manufactured home and, where necessary for stability, secured to the ground. Two access doors are required to be installed in a manner which will provide adequate access for inspections and maintenance. Provisions must be made for adequate ventilation for the crawl space underneath the manufactured home. (5) Additional living space is prohibited to be added to a manufactured home unless a set of plans is submitted to and approved by the city building inspector. This must be done prior to obtaining a building permit. (6) All manufactured home installations shall provide an adequate means of entry (steps) which shall be four feet by four feet and of height to be even with the bottom of the door face. (7) Any manufactured home existing on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be exempt from the regulations of subsection (4) of this section until such time as the manufactured home is relocated. When a manufactured home park or subdivision existing on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived is expanded, it shall meet all of the regulations of this chapter. (8) A manufactured home used for a commercial or industrial sales office shall comply with this chapter pertaining to the installation and setup of the unit. Use of this structure for living purposes is strictly prohibited. (9) Manufactured home units used temporarily during commercial construction are required to be registered with the building inspector. They shall not exceed 24 months at any one site or the duration of related construction projects unless approved by the building inspector. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 10.1) Sec. 56-202. - Compatibility standards for homes. (a) Single-family housing other than site built homes. Manufactured homes, modular and other housing qualifying as a dwelling, single-family, shall meet the following compatibility standards to protect and preserve the overall existing character of established neighborhoods and the property values of the residential district or areas shall apply to all housing in the R-2 Zone only. Compatibility standards are as follows: (1) Manufactured homes qualifying as dwelling, single-family, shall be compared to site built and other housing in the immediate general area within the same zoning or residential district or area. Approval shall be granted upon the finding that the manufactured home is substantially similar in size, siding material, roof material, foundation and general aesthetic appearance to: a. Site built or other forms of housing which may be permitted in the same general area under this chapter; b. Existing development; or c. Proposed development in the same zoning district or area. (2) All towing devices, wheels, axles and hitches must be removed. (3) Skirting will be required on all manufactured homes with materials approved by the planning commission. (4) The minimum width of the structure built or installed on the site shall be 16 feet or greater in all other residential districts. (5) The roof shall have a surface of wood shakes, asphalt composition, wood shingles, fiberglass, or metal tiles, slate materials or other materials approved by the planning commission. Corrugated metals or plastic panels are prohibited. (6) The exterior siding materials shall consist of brick, wood, masonry, stucco, masonite, metal or vinyl lap designed for such purposes or other materials of like appearance approved by the planning commission, but shall not included corrugated metal or plastic panels. (7) Be attached to a permanent foundation. A permanent foundation shall mean a concrete slab, concrete footers, foundation wall pilings or post construction which complies with the state minimum standard codes as amended from time to time or the standard building code (SBCCI), if locally adopted or the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act or the State of Georgia Industrialized Buildings Act. (8) Be constructed according to standards established by the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act or the State of Georgia Industrialized Buildings Act. (9) The planning commission may approve deviations from one or more of the developmental or architectural standards provided herein on the basis of a finding that the materials to be utilized or the architectural style proposed for the dwelling will be compatible and harmonious with existing structures in the vicinity. (10) These compatibility standards are not applicable and shall not be applied to manufactured homes located in a manufactured home rental community or park (R-3 zoning district), but shall apply to those manufactured homes on individual lots in both the R-2 and R-3 Zones. (b) Site built single-family homes. Site built single-family homes shall meet the following compatibility standards: (1) Site built housing qualifying as dwelling, single-family, shall be compared to manufactured housing and other housing in the immediate general area within the same zoning or residential district or area. Approval shall be granted upon the finding that the site built housing is substantially similar in size, siding material, roof material, foundation and general aesthetic appearance to: a. Manufactured housing or other forms of housing which may be permitted in the same general area under this chapter; b. Existing development; or c. Proposed development in the same zoning district or area. (2) The minimum width of the structure built or installed on the site shall be 16 feet or greater in all other residential districts. (3) The roof shall have a surface of wood shakes, asphalt composition, wood shingles, fiberglass or metal tiles, slate, materials or other materials approved by the planning commission. Corrugated metals or plastic panels are prohibited. (4) The exterior siding materials shall consist of brick, wood, masonry, stucco, masonite, metal or vinyl lap designed for such purposes or other materials of like appearance approved by the planning commission, but shall not included corrugated metal or plastic panels. (5) Be attached to a permanent foundation. A permanent foundation shall mean a concrete slab, concrete footers, foundation wall pilings or post construction which complies with the state minimum standard codes as amended from time to time or the standard building code (SBCCI), if locally adopted or the State of Georgia Industrialized Buildings Act. (6) Be constructed according to standards established either by the state minimum standard codes as amended from time to time or the standard building code (SBCCI). (7) The planning commission may approve deviations from one or more of the developmental or architectural standards provided herein on the basis of a finding that the materials to be utilized or the architectural style proposed for the dwelling will be compatible and harmonious with existing structures in the vicinity. (8) These compatibility standards are not applicable and shall not be applied to manufactured homes located in a manufactured home rental community or park (R-3 zoning district), but shall apply to those manufactured homes on individual lots in both the R-2 Zone. (Ord. of 8-19-1997, § 10.2) Sec. 56-203. - Manufactured home parks.
